Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Node: DC, Maryland, Virginia Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Description:
This effort involves the creation and implementation of an I-Corps Regional Node in DC/MD/VA (DMV) region through a partnership involving the University of Maryland College Park (UMD), the George Washington University (GWU), and Virginia Tech (VT). The proximity of the DMV node to the Washington, DC area's vibrant entrepreneurial R&D ecosystem is providing a valuable set of resources to the national I-Corps network. The node is leveraging the respective strengths of the three institutions to help guide the transition of scientific discoveries into technologies and products that benefit society. It is implementing two initiatives that are specifically designed to increase the success rate of participating teams: (1) establishing a formal DMV I-Corps Mentor Network designed to attract, train, and retain top-notch mentors and (2) offering a post I-Corps Support program to help teams with a series of follow-on activities (e.g., continued customer development, minimum viable product prototyping, technology transfer and licensing, fundraising, legal services, and hiring executive talent). The node is implementing an Online Nodal Network (ONN) that ties together and augments existing tools (e.g., LinkedIn, YouTube, Google Docs, Quora, LaunchPad Central); addressing the needs that are particularly valuable to the nature of I-Corps teams. The ONN aggregates rich content and makes it more readily accessible to the I-Corps user community. It further enables the mentor network to pool and share their expertise with multiple I-Corps teams. In addition, the node is studying the effect of I-Corps training on: (1) any adjustments in orientation toward firm creation, (2) the proportion of teams that reach initial profitability, (3) the time required to reach initial profitability, and (4) the resources expended (time, money) in the start-up process.

Broader Significance:
In addition to providing training to NSF team cohorts, the DMV node is managing a Regional DMV I-Corps program that is designed to train an additional 150 teams over a three-year period. Thirty-five of the top two hundred U.S. universities in R&D expenditures are within a 4-hour drive of the DMV node. The node is focusing on attracting teams from these top regional academic institutions, as well as from the many federal and state research labs that are unique to the DMV region (e.g., NASA, NIH, ARPA-E). The node is also engaging underrepresented minority participation and HBCUs through cooperation with the Graduate Degrees for Minorities in Engineering and Science, Inc. (GEM) consortium. It is implementing a GEM-endorsed initiative to increase the awareness of research commercialization opportunities. Small grants are being directed to promising HBCUs' teams in order to provide innovation training. The node is additionally leveraging the DMV's mentor network to support the HBCU teams.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most significant impact of the DMV I-Corps node project has been to pioneer new practices in innovation training that have disseminated throughout the country and become standards of practice nationwide:

a) The creation of the "short course" model. In 2015, the DMV node was the first to conceive of, propose, prototype, and launch a 2-week I-Corps training program (vs the 7-week national I-Corps program) with two objectives: 1) reach many more researchers in a much more cost-effective way, and 2) increase the number of teams admitted into the NSF national program. These 2-3 week short courses are attractive for to faculty and researchers because they are typically held at convenient times and locations on or near their campuses, usually within easy walking distance. The smaller cohort size (5-10 teams) allows for smaller teaching teams, abundant options for free/inexpensive venues, and far fewer logistics and operational requirements and expenses. The DMV node developed the syllabus, the curriculum, and a white paper that has been used by NSF and throughout the National Innovation Network (NIN) to help other schools offer these short courses.

b) The creation of the SBIR Beat the Odds Bootcamp, an adaptation of I-Corps for the NSF SBIR program. Along with NSF, the DMV node conceived of, prototyped, and launched a pilot in 2014 for select SBIR Phase I awardees that gave them training similar to the national NSF I-Corps program but with key differences designed to match the needs and format of the SBIR program. After a successful pilot, NSF tasked the DMV node with rapid expansion of the program. The DMV node recruited dozens of national instructors from all the nodes and now coordinates the training of all 300+ SBIR Phase I awardees each year. The SBIR Beat the Odds Bootcamp has become a core element of the NSF SBIR program. http://www.dcicorps.org/spring2019sbirphase1bootcamp/

c) The recruitment of the head of an HBCU I-Corps Site (Howard University) to regularly serve as one of the core teaching team members for the node's national cohorts. With NSF's help, this practice has subsequently spread to other nodes and has proven to be a highly effective way for nodes and sites to work together, share best practices, promote diversity and inclusion, and scale impact.

d) The expansion of the node by adding Johns Hopkins, the #1 federally-funded research university in the country, as a fourth university partner. This practice of officially adding new schools to a node has also subsequently spread to other nodes and has proven to be a highly effective way for a larger number of universities in a region to work together, share best practices, promote diversity and inclusion, and scale impact.

e) The HHS Ignite accelerator program. Together with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, the DMV node conceived of, prototyped, and launched the HHS Ignite accelerator program to support the exploration and testing of ideas that promise to modernize government and improve HHS's ability to carry out its mission. HHS Ignite has become the model exemplar of how the innovation principles in I-Corps can be adapted to other areas like public health. The goal of each Ignite team is to test both a low-res prototype and the business value of their idea with actual end-users. Since 2014, the node has taught eight cohorts to around 100 teams with projects from NIH, CDC, CMS, and many other divisions. https://www.hhs.gov/cto/initiatives/ignite-accelerator/about/index.html

f) Embedding I-Corps concepts into the undergraduate engineering curriculum as well as the core curriculum for students of all majors. Many I-Corps training variations were developed to better meet the needs and were better value propositions for the university student customer segment: online versions to reach large numbers of students at scale; small, bite-size modules focused on honing specific lean startup skills (e.g., interviewing and gaining empathy for stakeholders) and designed to be easily inserted into existing courses; adaptations where students were asked to think of themselves as startups and to apply the business model canvas to their majors and careers; train-the-trainer workshops specifically geared to faculty of all disciplines wanting to teach innovation in their courses; just to name a few.

g) A stronger DMV innovation network.  There are now over a dozen national I-Corps instructors and dozens more regional instructors and mentors who regularly teach and coach in numerous I-Corps programs throughout the DMV region to hundreds of teams each year. Any team from anywhere in our region can typically get access to just about any instructor or mentor in the DMV node and the combined areas of expertise of this extensive network. In short, the NSF I-Corps Node program has allowed the DMV node to create an "all for one, one for all" sense of community by bringing together this region's universities, investors, entrepreneurs, and industries in ways not previously possible before I-Corps.

  

 


Last Modified: 05/08/2019
Modified by: Dean Chang

Any team from anywhere in our region can typically get access to just about any instructor or mentor in the DMV node and the combined areas of expertise of this extensive network. In short, the NSF I-Corps Node program has allowed the DMV node to create an "all for one, one for all" sense of community by bringing together this region's universities, investors, entrepreneurs, and industries in ways not previously possible before I-Corps.
